title: 113_s825
content: The "Homeless Veterans Prevention Act of 2013" is also known as the Act. It aims to improve grant programs for comprehensive service programs for homeless veterans. The Act aims to modify authority for capital improvement grants assisting homeless veterans by adding provisions for physical privacy, safety, and security needs. Additionally, it increases per diem payments for transitional housing assistance that transitions into permanent housing for homeless veterans. Section 2012(a)(2) of title 38, United States Code is amended to redesignate subparagraphs and adjust rates for transitional housing assistance for homeless veterans. The maximum rate for transitional housing assistance for homeless veterans is set at 150 percent of the rate authorized for State homes for domiciliary care, with a provision for permanent housing placement. SEC. 4 authorizes per diem payments for care of dependents of homeless veterans receiving services from grant recipients. SEC. 5 requires the Department of Veterans Affairs to assess comprehensive service programs for homeless veterans. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must assess and measure the capacity of programs receiving grants or per diem payments to support homeless veterans. This assessment includes examining national and local levels to determine if there is enough capacity to meet the needs of homeless veterans in different geographic areas and subpopulations. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs assesses program capacity for homeless veterans, sets goals, evaluates program effectiveness, allocates funding, and improves veteran referrals. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress within 180 days of completing the assessment, including recommendations to enhance programs and per diem payments for homeless veterans. SEC. 6 repeals the requirement for annual reports on assistance to homeless veterans. SEC. 7 repeals the sunset on authority for referral and counseling services for veterans at risk of homelessness. SEC. 8 focuses on partnerships to provide legal services to homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness. The Secretary may enter partnerships with public or private entities to fund legal services for homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness, ensuring equitable distribution across the US, including rural areas and tribal lands. Legal services for homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness include housing-related assistance, family law support, income support, and criminal defense to reduce recidivism and help with reentry obstacles. The Secretary shall consult with public and private entities to develop partnerships for legal services for homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness, including assistance in identifying organizations and coordinating outreach relationships. Entities may be required to submit periodic reports on services provided. Expansion of Department of Veterans Affairs authority to provide dental care to homeless veterans. Expansion of Department of Veterans Affairs authority to provide dental care to homeless veterans. Subsection (b) of section 2062 of title 38, United States Code, is amended to extend eligibility for care to veterans enrolled under section 1705(a) receiving housing assistance or care in specified settings for 60 consecutive days. The Secretary may provide funds for a grant and per diem provider for specified settings. The Secretary can disregard breaks in assistance or care for which the veteran is not responsible. SEC. 10. EXTENSIONS OF AUTHORITIES. Section 10 extends various programs related to homeless veterans, including comprehensive service programs, reintegration programs, treatment for mentally ill veterans, centers for services, and housing assistance. Amendments include funding amounts for fiscal years, extension of deadlines from 2013 to 2014. Amendments to housing assistance and financial support for homeless veterans include extending deadlines to December 31, 2014, and allocating $300,000,000 for fiscal year 2014. Additionally, a grant program for homeless veterans with special needs will have $5,000,000 available for each fiscal year from 2007 to 2014. Amendments extend deadlines to December 31, 2014 and allocate $300,000,000 for fiscal year 2014. $5,000,000 available annually from 2007 to 2014 for grant program for homeless veterans with special needs.
